title: How to Wirelessly Transfer a Document to an Amazon Kindle Device

steps.headline: Locate your customized Send-to-Kindle email address from your settings in Amazon's page-settings.If you find that you don't have one yet, Create Your Send-to-Kindle email address.
steps.description: If you've already created one but forgot what it was and you have your device handy, this information can be found on any Kindle on the second page of your Kindle's settings.

steps.headline: Open a new email message on your PC or Macintosh computer.
Enter your Send-to-Kindle email address into the "To" box.
Attach the document as a downloadable attachment to your email.
Send the file on its merry-way.
Locate a place where Wi-Fi is accessible.
steps.description: If this place is your house, go to a place in your house that Wi-Fi has the best reception, along with a time when the Wi-Fi network has the highest bandwidth time by other users. If not, your library may have a Wi-Fi network, but check with your library before spontaneously going there, to see if they do or not.

steps.headline: Connect to the Wi-Fi network on your Kindle device, if it isn't already on.
steps.description: Even if your device has 3G capabilities, Amazon will only transfer files over Whispernet when Wi-Fi itself is on. If you don't have Wi-Fi  turned on, you'll receive a reminder document onto your device telling you that your documents are queued and ready to be transferred and that the documents will be transferred once you turn on Wi-Fi.

steps.headline: Give the device a few moments to initialize, convert and receive the entire document to your Kindle.
Look for the document on the Home screen of the device, or if the Kindle is one of the Kindle Fire tablets, as a Document title on the Carousel (home screen).

tyn: Most commonly, this is a PDF file, but this isn't limited to PDF files alone.

text: Locate your customized Send-to-Kindle email address from your settings in Amazon's page-settings.If you find that you don't have one yet, Create Your Send-to-Kindle email address. If you've already created one but forgot what it was and you have your device handy, this information can be found on any Kindle on the second page of your Kindle's settings. Open a new email message on your PC or Macintosh computer.  Enter your Send-to-Kindle email address into the "To" box.  Type "convert" in the subject box.  Attach the document as a downloadable attachment to your email.  Send the file on its merry-way.  Locate a place where Wi-Fi is accessible. If this place is your house, go to a place in your house that Wi-Fi has the best reception, along with a time when the Wi-Fi network has the highest bandwidth time by other users. If not, your library may have a Wi-Fi network, but check with your library before spontaneously going there, to see if they do or not. Turn on the Kindle device.  Connect to the Wi-Fi network on your Kindle device, if it isn't already on. Even if your device has 3G capabilities, Amazon will only transfer files over Whispernet when Wi-Fi itself is on. If you don't have Wi-Fi  turned on, you'll receive a reminder document onto your device telling you that your documents are queued and ready to be transferred and that the documents will be transferred once you turn on Wi-Fi. Give the device a few moments to initialize, convert and receive the entire document to your Kindle.  Look for the document on the Home screen of the device, or if the Kindle is one of the Kindle Fire tablets, as a Document title on the Carousel (home screen).
